all_paragraphs: Strings are seemingly simple datatypes in Python. But do you know what str.format_map does? Or str.expandtabs? No? Okay, how about str.isidentifier?
I, until very recently, had never heard of any of them — if you have, fair enough, I’m impressed.
Python’s string methods are varied, some very useful, others less so. But all have their unique use-cases nonetheless. We will take a look at some of the less common, but still useful features.
So, let’s take a tour around Python’s string methods.
A more aggressive version of lower. Whereas lower only works for ASCII characters [A-Z] -> [a-z] , casefold attempts to standardize non-standard characters, for example Latin or Greek.
This can work really well — the Olympian Hermes from Greek mythology, is written as Ἑρμῆς in Greek, in lowercase, this is ἑρμῆς.
In comparison, lower fails on this.

The second argument is optional, and defaults to " ".
Similar to center, these functions add padding to a string and left-align or right-align it respectively. Again, the default argument is " ".
This lets us count the number of times a pattern is repeated in a sentence.
Allows us to specify or change the string’s encoding type, the default is utf-8. If the string contains characters that are not included withing an encoding set, we will receive a UnicodeEncodeError.
We can adjust the behavior of the error handing scheme — the default being 'strict'. 'ignore' will ignore errors, 'replace' replaces them.
This replaces all tab characters with spaces, the default being eight spaces.
Similar to the format method, but allows us to use dictionaries. For example:
[Out]: "We have mapped the values from the dictionary"
partition is similar to split, but splits the string on the first instance of the given pattern, and also returns the given pattern. rpartition simply does the same but from the right of the string.
Where find returns the index of the first character in a string that satisfies the given pattern, rfind does the same but starts from the right of the string.
If the pattern is not found, find and rfind return -1.

Also the same as split, but splits by newline characters \n.
Swaps the case of characters, also works with non-English alphabets.
Allows us to swap out patterns using a translation dictionary built with the maketrans method.
Pads the beginning of the string with zeros until reaching the given length. If the given length is less than that of the string, no padding is done.
We also have many format checking methods, which return either True or False. Most are pretty self-explanatory so we will keep these short.
Is the string alpha-numeric, containing a mix of alphabetical and numerical characters only?
Is the string alphabetical, containing nothing but letters?
Does the string contain only characters from the 128-character ASCII encoding standard?
This one is a little more interesting, and unexpected, in behavior. It identifies strings that contain only Unicode decimal digit characters. This does not mean decimal numbers like 3.142.

The Unicode decimal digit characters cover the numeric digits themselves, in many different scripts. For example, it covers 0-9, it also covers the Bengali digit three ৩, and the Tibetan digit five ༥.
A full list of Unicode decimal digits can be found here.

This tells us if the string is a valid Python identifier, meaning we can assign it as the name of a variable, function, class, etc. It includes letters, numbers, and underscores. However, it cannot begin with a number.
Checks our string for any characters that are not directly printed to the console, like the newline character \n or tab \t.
Checks that the string contains space characters only (including newline \n and tab \t).

That is all! The number of string methods in Python is (at least to me) very surprising. Although I struggle to see the use-case for zfill (let me know if you have used it), the rest seem genuinely useful.
I hope this article has introduced you to at least a few of Python’s string methods.
